node.text:
Dr. Moira Dillon is an Assistant Professor of Psychology at New York University and the Director of the Lab for the Developing Mind. Dr. Dillon received her B.A. from Yale University and her A.M. and Ph.D. from Harvard University. Her work has been published in top research journals including Science and the Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences, and she has received numerous awards for early career scholars including from the National Science Foundation, the Jacobs Foundation, and the Association for Psychological Science. Dr. Dillon’s research focuses on infant and child cognitive development, including what infants know even before they start talking, how young children use pictures and language to think more abstractly, and how parents can foster school-readiness in STEM. Dr. Dillon is also “mom" to a lovable 1-year-old!

Follow her lab @labdevelopingmindnyu for more information and advice.

In this video, Dr. Dillon answers:

1. What are the thought processes of a baby?

2. What’s the single best thing parents can do for a baby’s cognitive development? 

3.  What’s the best way to develop cognitive abilities in babies and toddlers?

4. How do I foster school readiness? 

5. What’s the best age to teach baby sign language? 

6. When does a child develop a sense of self? 

7. What are some early signs my child is inherently smart or gifted, and how do I nurture that?

#expertadvice #cognitivedevelopment #infantdevelopment #babydevelopment #braindevelopment

node.title: Infant Cognitive Development: Dr. Moira Dillon

node.text:
Melissa is a mommy of two and a speech-language pathologist specializing in babies and toddlers. Melissa's passion is teaching parents how to talk to their little ones in a way that gets them talking back! She has helped thousands of parents get their young children talking through her Raising Little Talkers online course, her beloved Instagram page of the same name, and her private practice in Los Angeles. 

Follow her at @raisinglittletalkers for more advice and information.

In this episode, Melissa answers:

1. My child is 18 months old and says at least 50 words, but doesn’t say mama. What do I do? 

2. What is the best tip for helping a 1-year-old to imitate speech and gestures? 

3. Will speaking two languages to my baby slow down their learning to speak? 

4. My 12-month-old regressed from saying “mama” to no words for 2 months. When to worry? 

5. Is it bad to use nicknames for items like “susu” for soother? 

6. Does sign language help or hinder speech and language development? 

7. What’s an appropriate age for a speech and language evaluation?

#speech #language #SLP #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Melissa Minney, Part 1

node.text:
Melissa is a mommy of two and a speech-language pathologist specializing in babies and toddlers. Melissa's passion is teaching parents how to talk to their little ones in a way that gets them talking back! She has helped thousands of parents get their young children talking through her Raising Little Talkers online course, her beloved Instagram page of the same name, and her private practice in Los Angeles. 

Follow her at @raisinglittletalkers for more advice and information.

In this episode, Melissa answers:

1. My child is 18 months old and says at least 50 words, but doesn’t say mama. What do I do? 

2. What is the best tip for helping a 1-year-old to imitate speech and gestures? 

3. Will speaking two languages to my baby slow down their learning to speak? 

4. My 12-month-old regressed from saying “mama” to no words for 2 months. When to worry? 

5. Is it bad to use nicknames for items like “susu” for soother? 

6. Does sign language help or hinder speech and language development? 

7. What’s an appropriate age for a speech and language evaluation?

#speech #language #SLP #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.title: Speech and Language Development: Melissa Minney, Part 1

node.text:
Jenny Best is the founder of Solid Starts (@solidstarts), a team of pediatric food + feeding experts, doctors, nutritionists, and dietitians, and the world’s first comprehensive platform for starting babies on solid food. Solid Starts features the First Foods®️ database, a free food database and app complete with instructions and how-to videos for introducing real food to babies. Solid Starts serves more than one million people from 175 countries worldwide, offering complimentary resources to those facing economic hardship. 

Follow @solidstarts for more advice and information.

In this episode, Jenny answers:

1. What is baby-led weaning (BLW)?

2. How does choking happen?

3. What are the best foods to start with?

4. How can I do baby-led weaning with food allergies?

#solidstarts #feeding #babyledweaning #blw #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Is it okay to introduce a second language when neither parent is bilingual? Is it appropriative?

2. What’s the number one recommendation for encouraging a bilingual home (if you had to pick just one)?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a developmental psychologist and research scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. Do I have to be fluent in a language to teach my child?

2. What if only one parent is bilingual?

3. It’s hard to have one-sided conversations in a language.

4. Will learning another language delay my child’s speech?

5. Will speaking 2 or 3 languages confuse or overwhelm my child?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Veronica Fernandez, PhD, is a Developmental Psychologist and Research Scientist at the University of Miami. Her research focuses on understanding and improving the quality of interactions and early learning experiences for children. 

She uses inquiry and play as mechanisms to promote equity for cultural and linguistically diverse children, families, and teachers. Most importantly, she is the mommy of a curious and spunky bilingual toddler — so she is putting her research into practice every day.

Follow her at @cultivating.wonder_ for more advice and information.

In this episode, Veronica answers:

1. What is the best age for my child to learn a second language?

2. What are the benefits of bilingualism?

3. Why is it best to start a second language early?

#bilingual #multilingual #earlylearning #language #expertadvice

node.text:
Elina Furman is a Certified Infant Massage Instructor with over 15 years in the baby product industry. She is deeply passionate about spreading awareness about the importance of infant/child massage. She earned her certification after talking to many parents who were confused and bewildered about how to perform infant massage. 

By creating an educational platform and a massage enhancement tool, Elina hopes to bridge the gap of knowledge to help parents and underserved families explore this science evidence-based practice performed for thousands of years all over the world.
Follow her at @getkahlmi for more information and tips. 

In this IGTV, Elina answers:

1. What are the benefits of infant massage?

2. How to start and when to do it? How often? And until what age?

3. What if it seems like my baby doesn’t like massage?

4. Does infant massage help babies sleep better?

5. How do we continue with massage for older children?

6. Can massages relieve gas discomfort and can it be done before my baby gets to that point?

7. Are there any massages to help with teething?

#infantmassage #babydevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. What age to worry about common mispronounced letters? (ex. R as W) Should my baby get evaluated professionally? 

2. How can I encourage my 3 year old to expand his short sentences?

3. Will mask-wearing by teachers affect the speech development of my 4 month old at daycare?

4. Does using a pacifier until at least 6 months of age affect speech?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. Should I be concerned about my two year old having a lisp? What causes them? 
2. When should I be worried about other people not understanding my 2 year old? 
3. When should babies start babbling? Is it concerning if an 8 month old baby doesn’t babble? Tips to encourage babbling?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.text:
Gopika Kamdar, MA, CCC-SLP is a Licensed Speech-Language Pathologist with a passion for the human brain, early childhood development, and parent coaching.

Her work focuses on how all parts of development play an integral part of speech and language development. Follow her at @speechwithgopika for more advice and information.

In this episode, Gopika answers:

1. How will speech develop for children in a bilingual family? Will it cause a delay in their speech?

2. Tips to help a 3 year old with stuttering? Should I see a doctor right away?

Be sure to watch all 3 IGTV videos in this series to hear all of Gopika's answers to the top questions on speech and language development. ✨

#slp #speech #language #childdevelopment #expertadvice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'These four fun sensory activities help build your toddler's neural pathways.'.

node.text:
Sensory activities engage the body and mind in a way that builds critical neural pathways: children do something, and the environment around them reacts, forming new connections and associations. We all need feedback to grow and thrive, and this is particularly true of young children. ✨

Here are four sensory activities for your toddler or older child: 👇

🧼 Shaving Cream Play 

Shaving cream is inexpensive and so fun to squish through your fingers, which is why it’s a favorite sensory play ingredient. On a hot day, give your child a can of shaving cream and a hose with the water set to mist or fine spray, and let them play. They can be naked or in a swimsuit, and this is best done on a hard surface (a driveway, sidewalk, brick, or stone).

🎨 Painting with Frozen Paint

You can freeze washable paint (add a little water). A popsicle stick or toothpick make the perfect paintbrush. To get the “handles” to stay put, you can either wait until the paint is partially frozen, or cover the tray with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and poke the sticks through. Once they’re frozen, let them melt for a few minutes (this makes them easier to paint with) and give your child a large piece of paper and let them paint. They’ll enjoy how the texture changes and the colors mix as the paint cubes begin to melt.

🦶Painting with Feet

Lay out paper flat on the ground, and tape or weight the ends down with heavy objects. Dot the paper with washable paint. Use a variety of colors, but don’t use too much paint—small dollops, spaced a few inches apart, should do the trick. Invite your child to paint! If they need a little encouragement to use their feet, invite your child to try a finger first. They can explore how the paint moves and feels with a finger before trying their feet.

🧊Ice Cube and Salt Towers

At 31 months, many children can start building block towers in more complex ways, including making a bridge with three blocks and a tower with eight. As a fun twist, try it with ice cubes on a tray—their cold, slippery properties make them difficult to balance, but dipping an ice cube in salt (then waiting a few moments) before adding it to the tower helps it all stick together.

node.text:
"If I’m being honest I was a bit skeptical about the high contrast cards before Yitzchak was born. I kind of thought they were created as a way to sell a toy for newborns and that while, yes, the fact that they are images that babies can see is backed by science, they wouldn’t really grab the baby’s attention. Boy was I wrong. 

Yitzchak loves his black and white cards. He can stare at them for far longer than I can focus on any one thing. They even calm him when he is upset. Once again I am reminded just how much we underestimate babies. 

Concentration is so much more natural than I realized before. While I am giving him opportunities to develop this concentration through his black and white cards and mobiles, I also feel all the more sure of my decision to avoid toys that light up or make noise. His concentration is incredible and I don’t want to undermine that. 

Babies really are so much more capable than we give them credit for and he shows me this every day." - @homeandontheway 💕

#newborn #infant #lovevery #infantmilestones #wonderweeks  #newbaby #babydevelopment #newborndevelopment  #montessoriathome #childdevelopment #infantdevelopment #blackandwhitecards #babybraindevelopment

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Fact: When toddlers know they can make people laugh it builds their self-esteem. So be silly, laugh, and repeat! LOVEVERY RY'.

node.text:
People say a good laugh and a long sleep are the two best cures for anything. A long sleep may not be a luxury you can indulge in right now, but a good laugh we can do. 😉 ⁣
⁣
“Kids with a well-developed sense of humor are happier and more optimistic, have higher self-esteem, and can handle differences—their own and others’—better,” says Dr. Mary Gavin with Kids Health. 🙌⁣
⁣
Around 12-18 months, your toddler may begin showing they have a sense of humor. Their budding personality is a sign of their cognitive, social, and emotional development. Humor requires both sides of the brain—the left side for thinking of a joke, and the right side for appreciating it and laughing. 🧠⁣
⁣
Here are some ideas for nurturing your toddler's sense of humor: ⬇️ ⁣
⁣
- Be silly! Smiling, big facial expressions, funny noises, and peek-a-boo are all amazing ways to introduce humor to your toddler. Put hats on their feet or shoes on their head while getting dressed. Play a game of who can make the silliest face, or put on some music for a goofy dance-off. 🥳 ⁣
⁣
- Repeat funny happenings with your toddler! A joke never seems to get old at this age. Not only does your little one enjoy the repetition, but they also want you to laugh with them again and again. 🤪 ⁣
⁣
- Laugh when they do! Acknowledging and reacting to things they find funny builds their sense of connection with you as well as their sense of humor. Laugh along with them at a loud noise or a strawberry that fell on the ground. 😂 ⁣
⁣
- Read funny books together! The Being Silly mini board book has funny images you can imitate; any books that are silly and goofy promote the enjoyment of reading. 📚 ⁣
⁣
- Have fun with sounds! Make goofy sounds and funny noises with your mouth while you play. You can say “whoop” or “whoosh” when your toddler pushes the ball down the track. They may imitate and then you imitate and so on… hang in there with all the repetition and try to have fun. 🗣⁣
⁣
If comedy doesn’t come naturally to you, just be playful and laugh, luckily toddlers are an easy audience. 😜⁣

#lovevery #toddlers #toddlerlife #toddlerdevelopment #toddlerlearning #toddlermom

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on September 03, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'Tip: If you give your child something real real and right-sized sized for their little hands you are showing you respect them and view them as capable. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
Montessori principles believe in providing your child with real tools that are the right size for their little hands, this way your child can actively participate in practical life activities. 

Kylie from @howwemontessori explains: “Often as Montessori parents, we look for smaller but real versions of the adult's tools. A real but small shovel, a real but small hoe. Small materials are easier for the child to manipulate but are very different to toy, plastic or pretend versions. A Montessori parent doesn't give their child a plastic hammer, we give them a small but real hammer, we slowly over time show the child how to use it, we give them time to practice and use it along side us. Then the day comes when they are ready to use it by themselves. This may happen at three years or six but the child comes to this point themselves, through real experiences.” 

We have found that by creating real, but child-sized tools, such as, the Squeaky Clean Squeegee from the Enthusiast Play Kit or the Squeeze & Spray Mop from the Storyteller Play Kit might mean your windows and floors are extra clean… But it also means your child will get to participate in practical life activities that help your child feel more independent and develop a greater sense of confidence. 🥳

What other child-sized tools have you implemented into your household? 👇

#practicallife #montessori #montessoriprinciples #practicallifeactivities #lovevery

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lovevery on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Fact: Babies and toddlers of all ages benefit from sensory water play. LOVEVERY'.

node.text:
According to the National Association for the Education of Young Children the many benefits of water play range from: 👇

💫 Sensory exploration

🔢 From exploring complicated concepts like volume, weight, motion, sinking vs. floating, and containment -- there's a lot of STEM learning to be had.

🗣 There's so much to talk about with water play. Like the way it feels on your child's skin to introducing new words like splish, splash, drip and drop.

🧠 Water is a a true open-ended material. Children focus on the process of playing with the water rather than creating an end product. 

💪 From pouring, splashing, carrying, and lifting, your child is working many fine and gross motor skills all at once. 

All these benefits and more are why we have placed such an emphasis on water play throughout our Play Kit Subscription Program and have made sure to include ways to play that include water. Such as: 👇

💧 The Wobbler (from The Senser Play Kit) makes for a great tummy time sensory activity when placed on a baking sheet with water.

💧 The Drip Drop Cups (from The Inspector Play Kit) are a great addition to bath time to teach nesting, pouring, and containment.

💧 The Grooved Pitcher and Glass (from The Realist Play Kit) are Montessori classics that emphasize pouring practice and hand-eye coordination.

💧 The Super Sustainable Sink (from The Helper Play Kit)  includes a water basin that recycles the water — this way your child can run the water for hours without it going down the drain.

💧 The Squeaky Clean Squeegee Set (from The Enthusiast Play Kit) is the right size for your child’s hands and has a gentle mist that they will love to spray.

💧 The Liquid Lab (from The Investigator Play Kit) is a great introduction to STEM learning using water play.

💧The Squeeze and Spray Mop (from The Storyteller Play Kit) is another child-sized tool that helps them explore how liquids can help clean surfaces.

💧The Turtle Hatch Game (from The Problem Solver Play Kit) is a collaborative game to practice taking turns with water being a key component.

💧The Liquid Color Lab (from The Problem Solver Play Kit) allows your child to explore how color blends in water.

#lovevery

node.text:
This balloon kicking activity is one of our favorites! It’s a great way to strengthen gross motor skills. It also strengthens eye muscles to improve tracking and helps develop concentration. 👌⁣⁠

Around 5 months, your little one is figuring out that their legs and feet are a part of them! 👣 ⁠
⁠
When they kick, they start to understand that their body can create noise or movement… a fun way to understand cause and effect! 🙌⁣⁠
⁠
They are also building important neck strength by tucking their chin to look down at their legs and feet. This “chin tuck” helps build important muscles needed for rolling over from back to side, and then eventually from their back to belly.⁣⁠ 💪 ⁠
⁠⁠
Tie a couple of helium balloons loosely around your little one’s ankles and let them get comfortable. You can encourage them to start kicking by moving their legs for them and showing them how the balloons move.⁣⁠ 🎈⁠

Please be sure to supervise your baby during this activity and put materials safely away when play is done.

#babyactivities #babyactivity #grossmotorskills #athomeactivities #lovevery

node.text:
“Ignore the behavior” is common advice for handling tantrums, but it’s important to distinguish between behaviors and the child displaying them. 👇

Ignoring behavior means continuing to stay present physically and emotionally while not paying attention to writhing, whining, huffing, or anything else your child is doing. 👏

That said, if the behavior gets unsafe and can’t be ignored, you can try a strategy called “connection, then correction.” This means that before you correct their behavior, provide your child with a brief moment of connection—this may be putting a hand over theirs and saying, “I can see that you’re upset AND hitting is not okay.”

Tantrums at home are one thing; the public ones are trickier. First of all, they can be really embarrassing. Even though you know (hopefully) that tantrums don’t reflect on your parenting, it’s hard not to feel judged, especially if you have to abandon a half-filled grocery cart or cut a trip to the park short.

If your child starts hitting or otherwise hurting you or someone else, you may have to whisk them away to keep everyone safe. Give your child a quick notice: “I’m going to pick you up now and take you back to the car,” and then pick them up gently.

There are a lot of reasons young children have tantrums. Mostly, they’re just trying to find their voice and understand their place in the family and in the world. Of course, sometimes the reasons are purely biological: your child may be tired, hungry, sick, or off their normal routine. 🤪

Whatever the reason, tantrums are SO hard. We’ve all been there, and will probably be there again. Take a deep breath, focus on your little one, and remember that you are doing a great job. ✨

Click the link in our bio for more tantrum tips!

#lovevery #childdevelopment #tantrums #childbehavior #toddlers #toddlertantrums

node.text:
Researcher and professor Marty Rossmann studied a group of children for over 25 years, and found “the best predictor of young adults’ success in their mid-20’s was that they participated in household tasks when they were three or four.” 🙌

This makes so much sense, until you see your 3-year-old spread more crumbs around than they’re sweeping up. Doing tasks yourself can seem so much easier when you’re short on time, but teaching your child how to do chores is worth it, we promise. 😉

How you can help your child develop a positive relationship with household tasks: 👇

✨ Capitalize on work cycles:
A “work cycle” is a Montessori concept. It refers to a chunk of uninterrupted time that is devoted to exploring the environment and engaging with the materials inside it.

Thinking about chores as work cycles helps you break them into discrete phases and be specific when you model them. If you want to teach your child to help do the laundry you might highlight 4 steps: take a shirt out of the dryer, put it in a laundry basket, bring the basket into the bedroom, and then fold it. Three-year-olds love to imitate, so keep your movements slow and let your child copy what you’re doing.

👍 Offer child-size tools:
Look for child-sized brooms, laundry baskets, and mops to give your 3-year-old the greatest opportunity for success. Household tasks are a lot harder to do—let alone learn—with mops and brooms that are twice your child’s height, or baskets large enough for them to sit in.

Give your child the boost they need to accomplish real goals. For example, step stools in the kitchen and bathroom help your child reach things independently, and a laundry hamper in the bedroom reminds them to get put dirty clothes away.

👏 Make rituals out of your requests:
Letting your child pick a few cyclical activities—like feeding the dog or doing the laundry—gives them more opportunities to practice. This repetition allows them to build relationships with their contributions and find more success.

🥳 Have fun working together:
Joyful collaboration is a vital ingredient in your child finding meaning in chores and feeling like they’re a critical part of your family culture.

#lovevery
